document_title: Ventricular septal defect: Causes, symptoms and treatment
subsection_content:
There is no way to completely prevent ventricular septal defects, but maintaining a healthy and safe pregnancy greatly contributes to reducing the risk of congenital heart defects in newborns. Therefore, if you plan to become pregnant, follow the healthy lifestyle below to create a foundation for a healthy baby to be born:
Get enough vaccinations before pregnancy (influenza, measles - mumps - rubella, chickenpox, hepatitis B, diphtheria - pertussis - tetanus);; Don't smoke, learn how to control stress, anxiety, depression;; Have a nutritious diet; Supplement adequate vitamins and minerals, especially calcium, iron and folic acid; Limit drinking alcohol, beer, caffeine;; Exercise regularly with exercises suitable for pregnant women such as yoga, slow walking, swimming...; Prenatal check-ups on schedule, complete tests to screen for defects and genetic diseases that may occur in the fetus;; Tell your doctor if you have a congenital heart disease, or have a family history of it.
A healthy pregnancy is the foundation for healthy children to be born
